captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: So we've come down
here to beautiful Trenton, New

Jersey, in the heart of the
ghetto, a couple of blocks

away from the Trenton State
Penitentiary, to feature this
unbelievable 1973 Chevelle.

It's a car that you
never really see.

These cars were never really
that popular in '73 to '76, so

to see one now is kind
of a rare sight.

So today, we're going to cruise
the ghetto, we're going

to cruise by the prison, maybe
go through a couple of

tunnels, and explore what
this car has to offer.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

MIKE MUSTO: Alright, so we're
here with Sean Rich and this
wicked 1973 Chevelle.

Now, Sean, you've had this car
for the better part of, what,
14, 15 years?
SEAN RICH: 14 years.

I've had it since I
was 15 years old.
I'm 29, yeah.

It's gone through several
changes over the years.

This is the most recent, the
pro-touring scene, definitely

with budget in mind, and it's
just been a lot of fun.

MIKE MUSTO: And when we first
saw this car, it's one of

those things where you
can't ignore it.

And to have a '73 Chevelle,
it really is kind
of an oddball car.
SEAN RICH: Absolutely.

I can remember back in high
school when I first showed my

buddies the car, and they were
like that's not a Chevelle.

Everybody thinks about
the '70s or the '72s
or stuff like that.

But, for some reason, I kept
on it, I kept at it, and I

held onto it for all
these years.

And now it's getting the
recognition that
I think they deserve.
They're a cool looking car.

MIKE MUSTO: Well, I totally
agree with you.

I think the body style of this
thing, a lot of people
overlook them.

And it's like a lot of these
older cars, once you start

massaging them a little bit,
drop them a little bit, a

different set of wheels
and whatnot, a little
paint here and there.

And I think the key is really
the personal touches that
you've installed on this car.

There's so much, I think, of
your personality that comes
out in this machine.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

MIKE MUSTO: Right now, we're
behind the wheel of Sean
Rich's 1973 Chevy Chevelle.

The car, from the outside,
is just outstanding.

This car has got a personality
and a presence that is just
unbelievable.

You drive by, and people look
at this car, and you know

immediately that this car
is just all business.

It's not trying to pretend
it's something it's not.

It's not trying to pretend
it's a show car.

It's not trying to pretend
it's an LS7
powered whatever it is.

It's just a bad ass street
machine that Sean built to
love and enjoy.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

And he's had this thing since
he's been 14 or 15 years old.

He bought it for 1,400 bucks
after he saved the money from

a paper route that he used to
do, which is pretty cool.

And over the years this car has
been through a whole bunch
of different lives.

It's been yellow with black
stripes, side pipes, jacked

up, Cragars in the back
and in the front.

I mean, crazy bumblebee style,
you know what I mean?

Not like new Transformers
bumblebee, but like old crappy
Camaro bumblebee.
This is much better.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]
Under the hood--

when I first contacted you, you
were like, well, the car
is not that fast.

But yet we went for a ride,
and the thing is actually
pretty frickin' quick.

So what do you got
under the hood?

SEAN RICH: Maybe I'm just
used to it now.
It's a 350 Chevy.

Me and my uncle, Roger, we
built it in high school.

I did the heads and cam when
I got out of college.

It's got World Products
Sportsman II heads.

It's got a Comp cam, pretty high
lift, just your budget
bolt on stuff, Holley 650.

It's got some no name headers
that I had Jet-Hot coated.

MIKE MUSTO: Now as far
suspension, because when we

were going down, I had commented
that the ride is
actually pretty good.

And you throw it into a corner
and the car does really,
really well.
One of the reasons--

talk to everybody
about the tires.

You've got some big meat that
people might not realize
that's on this car.

SEAN RICH: Yeah, the front tires
and wheels are 17 by 9.
They're the Cragar soft 8s.

They probably weigh
60 pounds apiece.

But they're 285/40/17 in the
front, and then the back I had
stretched to 10 and 1/2.

And those are Cragar soft
8s as well, but they're

MIKE MUSTO: So you've got
some meat on this car.
SEAN RICH: Yeah, yeah.

SEAN RICH: And that's one thing
that I don't think a lot
of people know.

Like people look through
catalogs, and they look at

wheels and things like that. and
they go, well, like I want
an 18 by or 17 by 10.

But I can only get
into an 18 by 8.

You can modify that,
same way he did.

You can take a wheel in, you can
get it stretched, you can

get it widened to fit whatever
you want it to.
That's the beauty.

What I didn't realize, and what
I don't think many people

realize, is that you didn't
have to modify anything

underneath to fit a 285 up front
and you said you could

put a 335 back here
if you wanted to.

SEAN RICH: I probably
could, yeah.

There's still probably about 2
and 1/2 inches left to go on
the inside.

And if I decide to stretch these
wheels even more and

make them weigh 80 pounds
apiece, then we'll definitely,
we'll at least try.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

MIKE MUSTO: Some other details
on the inside of the car that

it's pretty cool to
take notice of.

First and foremost, and probably
the best one--

his grandfather's service
medal from World War II.

He was there at the Battle of
the Bulge, and it's Sean's

inspiration as he
built this car.

His grandfather always wanted to
be a racer, and that's why
he has that on the visor.

It's a really cool and a really,
really nice touch.

The car doesn't have any heat,
it doesn't have any A/C, so

what he did was he blocked the
A/C off with these nice panels
that match the dash exactly.

You would never know that
that's not factory.
It just looks the right way.

The stereo, honestly, apparently
Sean doesn't care

about music because,
you know what?

He's got a cassette in this
sucker from like 1983.

But with this sound
and this noise, do
you really need music?
It's all the music I need.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

SEAN RICH: I got onto
Pro-Touring.Com, and I started

following some of the
Streetfighter builds, just

because it was a little
bit more obtainable.

I couldn't go for the high
dollar builds, so I started to
have this in mind.

I wanted something
that was sleek.

I wanted something that if I
were to build a car to rob a
bank, this is what I'd build.

MIKE MUSTO: Just so everybody
knows, the first sentence I

think you had said when
I said why did you
build this like this?

You were like-- and that's
exactly what you said.

If I needed to rob a bank, this
is exactly what I would--

and I was like that was the
greatest line I've ever heard.

Everything on this car was
basically done by you, because

you were a former
body guy, right?

SEAN RICH: Yes, I worked for
Gary Betsy's Performance

Restorations right down the road
here, and I went to Vo
Tech in high school.

Eventually, I went to college
for industrial design, but I

always stayed with my roots
and I always just loved to
build stuff.

And, like I said before, I just
kept at it, and this is
what it is.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

MIKE MUSTO: From a power
perspective, the car is not

like a massively
powerful beast.
It's got about 400 horsepower.

But you know what's beautiful
about that?

In a car this big, that weighs
about 4,000 pounds, that's

about 17 feet long, you can
utilize every last bit of it,
which is outstanding.

And the nice part is you don't
have to worry about getting

yourself into that
much trouble.

You go out, you've got your
400 horsepower, you're not

going to worry about making
the ass swing out coming
around corners.

If you're coming out of
a turn, you don't have
to worry about it.

He's updating the things
that need updating.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

MIKE MUSTO: Most people would
say ah, I'm going to put 700

horsepower in this thing, and
they forget that they have to

stop it, they forget that they
have to turn it, they forget
that, you know what?

Maybe I should invest in a good
set of tires, so that

when I do try to stop it, I
don't slide off the road on my

budget Costco units that
I frigging spent 80
bucks a shot on.
He did it the reverse.

He said let me upgrade the
suspension, let me upgrade the

brakes, let me update the
tranny, the rear end, and
everything else.

And he did it, and what he's got
is an absolutely fabulous,
well thought out package.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

MIKE MUSTO: So one of the best
parts about owning a muscle
car is going through a tunnel.

Tunnels and muscle cars, well,
they go together like kibbles

and bits, like peanut
butter and jelly.
And they sound outstanding.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

How could you not love
this, really?
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

MIKE MUSTO: A lot of guys are
going to look at this car and

they're going to go, well, fine,
it's a '73 Chevelle, not

the best body lines
in the world.
But you know what?
I don't care.

And the best part is,
Sean doesn't care.

He doesn't give a crap
what you think,
'cause it's his car.

He did things to match
his personality.

The front end is off
a Chevy Laguna.

It's a very rare piece, but
he managed to find it.

He's still got drum brakes back
here, but they only do

20% of the stopping,
so screw it.
Who needs them?

He upgraded the front with Big
6 piston/pots, and they stop

this car extremely,
extremely well.
The tranny, T56 TREMEC--

beautiful unit, feels good,
shifts really, really well,

and keeps the car in a great
state of, I don't know, going
forward possibly?
[LAUGHING]

[CAR ENGINE RACING AND
TIRES SQUEALING]

MIKE MUSTO: A lot of people
don't have a plan.
They just bolt [BLEEP]
together.

But with this one, again, as
soon as you look at it,
everything flows beautifully.

From the duck tail spoiler,
which you made, to the front

splitter on the front, to the
paint, to the wheels, it's a

beautifully put together
package.

Did you plan that out from start
to finish, or did you

start it off and be like, eh,
check this box, this box, or--
SEAN RICH: Well, thanks.

I kind of went along and I
did have this in my head.

I wanted something dark, a
little bit shady going down
the street.

Dark wheels, darker paint,
just something subdued.

I went from this daffodil yellow
with bumblebee stripes

to this, and this
is definitely a
little bit more timeless.

MIKE MUSTO: Are your plans to
take it even further, or just,

right now, just enjoy it the way
it is, take it out, track
it, and enjoy it?

SEAN RICH: I definitely want
to enjoy for awhile.

I know my wife wants me to stop
spending a little bit of
money on this.

But, eventually I will get the
disks for the back, and I have
plans to lighten it up.

That's what I really
would like to do.

I'd like to make it less
of a street car and
more of a race car.

And still drive it on
the street, but I'd
love to cage it.

I'd love to lighten it up,
lighter wheels for sure,
probably LS power.

This is all a checklist
down the road.
MIKE MUSTO: Sure.

SEAN RICH: But, right now, I
just want to have fun with it

and see how far this little high
school motor will take me
and that's pretty much it.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]

MIKE MUSTO: So I've really got
to take my hat off to Sean.

Not only did he build great
machine, but he built us a car

that we could showcase on Big
Muscle, and, for us, it's a

great way to end our
first season.

Thanks, Sean, we appreciate
it, man.
[CAR ENGINE RACING]
MIKE MUSTO: A lot of times--

I always say this-- this
is a fabulous car.
This is a great car.

And we get comments that say,
well, why don't you say

something negative
about the car?

When I find something negative,
I'll friggin' tell
you about it.

Also, you guys always yell
at me about my patina.

Let me tell you something
about patina.

This car doesn't have any, and
when I get home, I'm going to

put patina on my pasta, I'm
going to put it on my ice

cream, I'm going to shake a
little patina on my steak, and

I'm going to love every
minute of it.

So I gotta say, thanks for
sticking with us on this first

season, and the only thing that
we're going to do is try

to make this show better
for you guys.

So please, keep the suggestions
coming.

We want to know what you think,
why you think it, and

at day's end, what
you want to see.

We're going to try to bring
it to you, I promise.
So the day has come to an end.

We've spent it with Sean Rich,
his wicked '73 Chevelle, and
we've had a great afternoon.

When we do these shoots, these
cars are run for nine to 10
hours at a time.

Start, stop, we do so much with
them, and we've never had

a car fail on us, which is a
testament to how they're built

by the owners and how much care
is put in these things.

The other thing is this is our
season one finale, which

means, you guys, the commenters
helped make us make

a great show for you, and it's
been a wonderful experience.

As always, we're looking for
more cars, so email us at

drivebigmuscle@gmail.com if you
want your car featured.

Look at this '73 Chevelle, look
how bad ass it is, and

get some ideas, because this
what this show is all about.

It's about taking your ideas,
making them fantastic, and in

the end of the day, creating
a great car.

But also, stay tuned for the
credits, because we've got a
special treat coming for you.
[OUTTAKES SET TO MUSIC]

It makes you giggle, and
it makes you smile.
Listen to that.
Unbelievable.
[BLEEP]
Who cares.
Unbelievable.
Outstanding.
Pretty frigging cool.
Fantastic.
Who cares.

And I'll be honest with
you, you're an idiot.
Who cares.
[BLEEP]
Best thing ever.
Cherry on top.
[LAUGHING]
So sorry.
Go.
Helps tie everything in.
Who cares.
Tie everything in.
Patina.

title: 1973 Chevrolet Chevelle: Bank Robber's Special -- /BIG MUSCLE
